L.T. on a scow, traversing a canal, in the Shan States, in Burma. Notice the native holding umbrella over the camera. The heat was so intense that an umbrella was always raised whenever the camera went into use, to keep the chemicals on the film from melting.

Note: L.T. on a scow, traversing a canal, in the Shan States, in Burma. Notice the native holding umbrella over the camera. The heat was so intense that an umbrella was always raised whenever the camera went into use, to keep the chemicals on the film from melting.
How's this for a Burmese cupid?
Note: How's this for a Burmese cupid?

L.T. and the private river steamer he used on one of his recent expeditions in Southern Asia. Note: The Irrawady River is one of the mighty rivers of the earth. It is to the Asiatic country of Burma what the Mississippi River is to the central states of U.S.A. In fact it is even more, because it is the principal artery of travel. To a considerable extent the life of Burma flows up and down the mighty Irrawady. For more than a thousand miles, as you journey up the river from the Bay of Bengal, from Rangood to Mandalay, you are never out of sight of the Burmese Pagoda, a Buddhist place of worship. Lowell Thomas and his party used this special river steamer as their base on an expedition which took them far up the Irrawady, and on many side trips into the jungle.
Verso: L.T. and the private river steamer he used on one of his recent expeditions in Southern Asia.

This is the burning ghat on banks of the sacred Ganges. There are 5 corpses burning. The white spots you see are the feet sticking over the logs. The figure un the center is being prepared- no logs have been put on top of him yet. On the right is a corpse being prodded along so it will burn better. If you look carefully you can see two baked legs!

On the remote and seldom visited southwestern coast of India, in the ancient seaport of Cochin, we found an extraordinary colony of Jews. Their patriarchs told us that their ancestors were exiled to this part by ancient Babylonian King Nebuchadnezzar. By these Jews are now divided into two groups, one called the white Jews and the other the black. Their customs are the same as the customs of the ancient Israelites of thousands of years ago. Lowell Thomas Travelogues

The Amir has recently had this famous sign [IT IS ABSOLUTELY FORBIDDEN TO CROSS THIS BORDER INTO AFGHAN TERRITORY] torn down. For years it has stood at the central Asian end of the grim Khyber Pass. It took Lowell Thomas two years to get past it, but the Amir is now eager for visitors to journey to his far off mountain realm.

Afghanistan-No. 28; Between the cities of Jellalabad and Kabul the party stopped for one night at the mountain village Nimlah in one of the Amir's rest-houses. This was surrounded by a high wall and a beautiful park of cypress trees. The trees were said to have been planted by the Emperor Jahangir, one of the great Moghuls. In addition to the avenues of symmetrical trees, there are gardens and fountains similar to those around the Taj Mahal. The reception which Mr. Lowell Thomas and party received here reminded them that they had left behind lands where European customs are prevalent. A midnight dinner fit for an oriental monarch was prepared for them. Eight swarthy Central Asians, with baggy trousers, huge turbans and slippers with upturned toes, came in single file each bearing a silver slaver covered with Afghan viands seasoned with spice and garlic. The last course included slabs of watermelon, and grapes that California would be proud of. Then squads of soldiers camped in a circle around the beds of the Amir's guests which were spread on the lawn. The soldiers were there to see to it that no prowler came near with his knife

Afghanistan-No.36., The Cobbler's Stall in Kabul occupies the same social place that the Village Blacksmith shop does in America. The country is mountainous and rocky. Most of the natives walk. Therefore they must be heavily shod. Most of them wear sandals of untanned leather, with upturned curved toes, and soles an inch thick studded with enormous iron hob-nails

Afghanistan-No. 37., Through the heart of the Amir's capital runs the historic Kabul River. The main bazaar commences at this point. The bridge in the distance is covered over after the fashion of the Ponte Vecchio over the Arno at Florence. On both sides are the stalls of sandal sellers and of vendors of bright coloured cloth, and ices. All the streets of the main bazaar in Kabul are covered over with a crazy patchwork of gunny-bags as though fashioned by a futurist artists crazed with drinking too many bowls of bhang. As a result of these canopies the streets are like tunnels. They are dark, gloomy and reeking with the mingled aromas of all the choicest smells of Cairo, Constantinople, Damascus, Bagdad, Benares, and Bokhara. They are several miles in extent and usually packed with fierce looking wild tribesmen from every corner of Central Asia. Many of them regard the killing of an Unbeliever the surest way of going to Paradise. Often they go wild with religious fanaticism. When that happens to a man he is called a Ghazi, and he starts out with his dagger resolved to disembowel an Unbeliever. So it was a good thing that a part of the Amir's bodyguard always accompanied the party when they went to the Kabul bazaar

Afghanistan-No. 39., Kabul extends for a mile and a half from east to west and a mile from north to south. It is hemmed in by barren mountains. Over the tops of these mountains runs a jagged, ruined ancient wall which looks like a miniature Great Wall of China. Sanitation in its modern sense is as unknown in Kabul as it was in Jerusalem before Allenby captured it. The present Amir is at work on a new capital in the fertile Chahardeh Valley midway between Kabul and his Summer palace in the Paghmam Hills twenty miles distant. This new city was planned by his grandfather, the great Amir Abdur Rahman

Afghanistan No. 49, The greatest ruler Afghanistan has had for many decades was Abdur Rahman. He conquered the country by winning the allegiance of the wild tribes. He built roads and opened up schools. But during the reign of the late Habib Ullah the schools were closed and the teachers put in prison. Some of the orthodox Mohammedan priests who had the ear of the Amir persuaded him that the schools were plotting against him. However, the new occupant of the throne has reopened them and established many more. Abdur Rahman did much to improve the country by introducing fine breeds of animals and agricultural products from other lands. Flocks form and main wealth of the nomad population. Among the products grown in some of the fertile valleys are wheat, barley, lentils, rice, millet, maize, turnips, potatoes, and other garden stuffs, tobacco, delicious melons and fruits of all kinds. The castor-oil plant grows everywhere and is widely used as a purgative by the Hakims or physicians who prescribe it for all ailments from sore eyes and liver complaints to rheumatism and baldness. There are barbers and others with complete lack of knowledge of anatomy who practice the art of surgery with much the same skill that one would expect a British bricklayer of blacksmith to exhibit

Afghanistan No. -54-, Reading from left to right: Prince Hayat Ullah Khan; Prince Mohammed Kabir Kahn who is the Amir's youngest brother and the Postmaster General; Adadud Dawla Khan who is Minster of Defense; Prince Ineyet Ullah Khan eldest brother of the Amir, who is garbed in a robe and white turban; His Majesty, the Amir; Shah Wali Khan, Field-Marshal of the Army; Janabala Mahmud Bey Tarzy, the Amir's father-in-law; Mohammed Ishaq, Chancellor of the Afghan Foreign Office. Afghanistan-No. 63., General Fakri Pasha, who represents the "Young Turks" at the Amir's Court, won considerable fame during the world war, first at the defense of the Dardanelles and then when transferred to the Arabian Desert to fight the forces of the King of the Hedjaz and Colonel Lawrence. He made his headquarters at Medina, the forbidden Moslem city where the Prophet's tomb is located. Although his hope was a forlorn one he managed to defend Medina right up to the end of the war, and when Turkey finally capitulated he hurled defiance at the Allies and declared that he and his followers at Medina would fight until the last man was dead. He persisted in this attitude until after the Turks signed the armistice. But some days later his colleagues convinced him that things were hopeless and he finally consented to surrender to the combined British and Arab forces. General Fakri is believed to weild [sic] a powerful influence at the Court of the Amir. He has the appearance of a straightforward blunt old solider, and is a charming man to meet

He made his headquarters at Medina, the forbidden Moslem city where the Prophet's tomb is located. Although his hope was a forlorn one he managed to defend Medina right up to the end of the war, and when Turkey finally capitulated he hurled defiance at the Allies and declared that he and his followers at Medina would fight until the last man was dead. He persisted in this attitude until after the Turks signed the armistice. But some days later his colleagues convinced him that things were hopeless and he finally consented to surrender to the combined British and Arab forces. General Fakri is believed to weild [sic] a powerful influence at the Court of the Amir. He has the appearance of a straightforward blunt old solider, and is a charming man to meet

Afghanistan-No.66; Amir Amanullah's Kabul palace, where public audiences are held, and where he meets foreign representatives on state occasions. The countries which have established legations in Kabul recently are the Bolsheviks, the new republic of Bokhara, Angora, China, India, and Italy. The representative of Moscow is a young Russian naval officer named Towareesh Roskolnikof. The minister from Italy is the Marquis Paterno

Afghanistan

Afghan-No. 67; Dil Kusha Palace, the Amir's residence in Kabul, is a two story, semi-European structure. Around it is an inner and an outer fort, and between them a deep moat. Two regiments guard the palace day and night, one occupying the inner fort and the other the outer. The general effect when viewed from the balcony of the Foreign Office is a strange medley of orient and occident. Around the palace are beautiful gardens. The present Amir seems almost as fond of gardens as were his illustrious predecessors the Great Moghuls

Afghan-No. 69, Several miles east of Kabul is another palace on a rocky hill. Behind it loom jagged mountains. Beneath it lies the fertile valley of the Kabul River. In the distance is one of the Amir's rookeries shaped like a fort. The lamp posts on either side of the Buick are of foreign design, and look as though they might have supported too many courtiers who have dined well but not wisely. But Afghanistan is the strictest prohibition country on Earth. There is no "Three-Mile-Limit� law," yet it is bone-dry. Even if these lamp posts do not indicate it. Inside the palace are quaint European furnishings. It seems strange in a country where they make gorgeous oriental carpets that one should fine the most conventional of "Axminsters" in the royal palace. There also is a ping pong table. It's difficult to imagine Afghans playing ping pong

Afghanistan -75-, One of the most prominent objects in Kabul is a white Column-of-Victory in the boulevard leading to the Great Mosque. Despite the fact that the Afghans have been defeated in all three of their wars with British India, this column was erected to commemorate the "victory" of the Afghans over the British Empire in the last war. On either side of the monument is a statue of an ancient Afghan warrior in coat-of-mail. At night the monument is illuminated. The column is more particularly to commemorate the battle of that in 1919 where the British suffered a temporary reverse
